script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Welcome to the Come Follow Me Podcast by Gospel Study App. I'm Sarah.

script.speaker: David
script.text: And I'm David. Happy to be here!

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: David, I have to start with a mystery that’s been nagging at me. In Moses 1:30, Moses asks God, 'Tell me … why these things are so.' Why does God create all these worlds? And here’s the deeper puzzle: what does His answer reveal about our purpose that most people completely miss?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Sarah, that’s a profound question, and it cuts to the heart of everything. God’s response in Moses 1:39 is staggering: 'For behold, this is my work and my glory—to bring to pass the immortality and eternal life of man.' Notice, it’s not just about creation for creation’s sake. There’s a personal, eternal purpose tied to us, and I think that’s where the real mystery unfolds.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Wait, that’s fascinating, but how does that connect to us individually? I mean, Moses is seeing countless worlds, endless creations—how does this grand scale boil down to me or you? I need to understand this.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Exactly, Sarah, and here’s where it gets powerful. Let’s look at multiple perspectives. From Moses’s view in Moses 1, he’s overwhelmed by the vastness of God’s creations, yet God calls him 'my son' in verse 6, personalizing it. Then, in Abraham 3:22-23, we see the premortal existence where we were among the 'noble and great ones'—chosen before the world was. This isn’t just cosmic; it’s deeply individual.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: So you’re saying God’s work isn’t just about worlds, but about us as His children? That’s a shift. How does that perspective change when we look at Christ’s role in this plan?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Precisely. Christ is central. In Abraham 3:24, we learn that 'there stood one among us that was like unto God,' who would 'make an earth whereon these may dwell.' Christ’s role as Creator and Redeemer ties directly to God’s work of immortality and eternal life. It’s not just ancient history—it’s the foundation of our eternal progression.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I love that connection. Let’s dive into a pattern I’m seeing here. There’s this theme of identity—knowing who we are—running through both Moses 1 and Abraham 3. Can we trace that across dispensations to see how it builds?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Absolutely, let’s map this out. In Moses 1:4, God declares, 'Behold, thou art my son,' affirming Moses’s divine identity. Then in Abraham 3:22-23, we see our premortal identity as spirits before the world was. Fast forward to Christ’s teachings in the New Testament, like in John 1:12, where we’re told we can become 'sons of God' through Him. And today, President Russell M. Nelson emphasizes in his talk 'Choices for Eternity' that knowing our true identity as children of God shapes every decision we make.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s remarkable! So this theme of divine identity isn’t just a one-time revelation—it echoes across time. I’m curious, though, how does this pattern hold up when we face opposition, like Moses did with Satan in Moses 1:12-26?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Great question. Notice this: Satan attacks identity directly. In Moses 1:12, he says, 'Moses, son of man, worship me,' trying to strip away the divine title God gave him. But Moses clings to his identity, responding in verse 13, 'Who art thou? For behold, I am a son of God, in the similitude of his Only Begotten.' This pattern of identity as a shield against temptation repeats in Christ’s temptations in Matthew 4 and even in modern prophetic counsel to know who we are.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I never saw that before—identity as a shield. That’s powerful. Let’s pivot for a moment to some historical context. Are there cultural or archaeological insights from Moses’s time that deepen our understanding of this identity theme?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Yes, and this creates a real time-collapse moment. In ancient Near Eastern cultures, including those surrounding Moses, identity was often tied to lineage and covenant relationships with deity. To be called a 'son' of a god was to be part of a divine covenant family, with rights and responsibilities. When God calls Moses 'my son' in Moses 1:6, it’s not just personal affection—it’s a covenant declaration, aligning Moses with a divine purpose, much like we see in later Israelite theology.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s so insightful! It makes me feel like I’m standing in Moses’s sandals, hearing God’s voice with that cultural weight. How does this connect to another piece of history, maybe something about Abraham’s vision in Abraham 3?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Here’s something fascinating. Abraham’s vision in Abraham 3, where he sees the stars and learns about the order of creations, mirrors ancient Mesopotamian astronomical knowledge—Abraham’s cultural backdrop. Texts from that era, like the Enuma Elish, show a deep fascination with cosmic order, but Abraham’s revelation reorients it to God’s plan for His children, not just celestial mechanics. It’s a stunning reframing: the stars aren’t just objects; they’re tied to souls and eternal progression, as seen in Abraham 3:22-26.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Wow, that’s a paradigm shift. So, circling back to our opening mystery—why does God create, and what’s the deeper purpose we miss? How does all this resolve that question for you?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Sarah, here’s what shifts everything. God’s creations, as vast as they are, exist for us—to bring about immortality and eternal life, as He says in Moses 1:39. The purpose we often miss is that we’re not bystanders; we’re the reason. Every world, every star, ties back to His covenant love for us, His children, to help us become like Him through Christ.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s beautiful. It’s not just about creation—it’s about family. I’m seeing now why Moses’s question and God’s answer are so pivotal. It reframes everything.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Exactly! And this is where hidden connections come in. Look at how Moses 1:39, 'my work and my glory,' links to Doctrine and Covenants 93:29, where we learn 'man was also in the beginning with God.' Then tie that to Abraham 3:24-25, where the plan is to prove us herewith. It’s a web of purpose across scriptures, showing God’s consistent focus on our eternal potential.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I’m blown away by that cross-reference. It’s like a thread weaving through all dispensations. What’s another connection most people might overlook?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Here’s one I love. In Moses 1:6, God tells Moses, 'all things are present with me, for I know them all.' Compare that to Abraham 3:19, where God says, 'I am the Lord thy God, I am more intelligent than they all.' Both verses reveal God’s omniscience, but they also hint at our potential to grow in knowledge and become like Him, as hinted in Doctrine and Covenants 88:107, where we’re promised to 'be made equal with him.'

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s incredible. It’s like a roadmap to divinity hidden in plain sight. How does this connect to the opposition we face, like Moses did with Satan? Is there a cross-reference there?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Definitely. Moses’s encounter with Satan in Moses 1:12-26 parallels Christ’s temptation in Matthew 4:1-11. In both, the adversary challenges identity and offers counterfeits—worship me, turn stones to bread. But both Moses and Christ reject the counterfeit by affirming their divine connection, and we see this echoed in modern counsel, like Elder Gary E. Stevenson’s talk 'Deceive Me Not,' warning us to recognize Satan’s fakes today.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s such a practical connection. It makes me think about how these ancient stories apply to us now. How can understanding our identity as children of God, like Moses did, shape our daily choices?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Sarah, this is where it gets real. President Nelson taught in 'Choices for Eternity' that 'the way you think about who you really are affects almost every decision you will ever make.' If we internalize that we’re children of God, it influences how we treat ourselves, others, even how we face temptation. It’s not just theology; it’s a lens for life—choosing kindness, resisting despair, seeking growth.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I love that. It’s like our identity becomes a compass. What’s one specific way you’ve seen this play out, maybe in how we resist modern counterfeits like Moses resisted Satan?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Here’s an example. Today, social media often peddles counterfeits of worth—likes, followers, external validation. But if we anchor in Moses 1:13, where Moses declares, 'I am a son of God,' we can reject those fakes and seek validation from God through prayer and covenant-keeping. It’s the same principle Moses used: know who you are, and the counterfeits lose power.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s so relevant. It makes me want to pause and reflect on my own identity. David, as we wrap up, what’s one invitation you’d give our listeners based on what we’ve uncovered today?

script.speaker: David
script.text: I’d invite everyone to take a quiet moment this week and read Moses 1:4-6, where God calls Moses His son. Then ask yourself, 'How does knowing I’m a child of God change how I see myself and my choices?' Write down one decision you’ll make differently because of that identity. I think you’ll feel a shift in perspective.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s a powerful invitation. I’m going to take that challenge myself. Thank you, David, for helping us unravel this mystery of God’s purpose and our place in it. It’s been eye-opening.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Thanks, Sarah. It’s always a joy to dig into these truths together. I’ve learned so much from this conversation!
